situation: A few players are playing a boardgame. The current state of the game is as follows. The peafowl has 61 dollars. The worm has 36 dollars, is a physiotherapist, and is currently in Lyon. The dalmatian does not pay money to the mermaid. And the rules of the game are as follows. Rule1: From observing that an animal does not swim in the pool next to the house of the husky, one can conclude the following: that animal will not hide the cards that she has from the swallow. Rule2: If at least one animal borrows one of the weapons of the poodle, then the swallow does not refuse to help the stork. Rule3: From observing that one animal pays some $$$ to the mermaid, one can conclude that it also hides her cards from the swallow, undoubtedly. Rule4: For the swallow, if you have two pieces of evidence 1) the dalmatian hides her cards from the swallow and 2) the worm does not destroy the wall built by the swallow, then you can add swallow refuses to help the stork to your conclusions. Rule5: Regarding the worm, if it works in healthcare, then we can conclude that it does not destroy the wall built by the swallow. Rule1 is preferred over Rule3. Rule4 is preferred over Rule2.
question: Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the swallow refuse to help the stork?
label: unknown
